instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED] 820-3662 Vcore Present @1.72V No Chime
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here with VCORE stuck at 1.72V and not chiming. I thought it might be BIOS related so I flashed a new clean file, but still no luck, same results. I'm inspecting the board to see if I can find any obvious hints like corrosion or etc. Board has a few little green stuff but nothing major. No apparently bad solder joints or rotten components. For what I understand 1.7V VCORE means the board is missing some kind of communication between CPU and BIOS right? What should I look?

threads.title: [SOLVED] 820-3662 Vcore Present @1.72V No Chime
threads.message:
These old boards doesn't switch VCORE in the same manner at new ones.

PLT_RST_BUF_L goes high?

threads.title: [SOLVED] 820-3662 Vcore Present @1.72V No Chime
threads.message:
Apart of known good BIOS, you can try heating PCH and CPU.
Possibly bad CPU.

Continue inspecting for some corroded resistor, or trace.
Pay atention to SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.

threads.title: [SOLVED] 820-3662 Vcore Present @1.72V No Chime
threads.message: Do you have a known good BIOS for me to test? Maybe the one I have here is bad... Will check the resistors... Could not find any corrosion and already tried heating CPU, will try also the PCH.

threads.title: [SOLVED] 820-3662 Vcore Present @1.72V No Chime
threads.message: R6123 was reading 203ohms. Replaced it and worked! Thanks!
